title: R43557
content: The first section of the report outlines the FY2015 legislative branch appropriations process, including the initial request submission, hearings by House and Senate Subcommittees, markups by House Subcommittee on Legislative Branch and House Committee on Appropriations, passage of H.R. 4487 by the House on May 1, 2014, markup and reporting of H.R. 4487 by the Senate Appropriations Committee on June 19, 2014, and enactment of continuing appropriations resolutions (P.L. 113-164) on September 19, 2014. The report details the legislative branch appropriations process for FY2015, including the passage of H.R. 4487 by the House on May 1, 2014, markup and reporting by the Senate Appropriations Committee on June 19, 2014, and the enactment of various appropriations acts. It also covers prior year actions and funding, with historical tables, and addresses FY2015 budget requests, hearings, and funding issues. The report discusses the legislative branch appropriations process for FY2015, including the passage of H.R. 4487 by the House on May 1, 2014, and the enactment of various appropriations acts. It also covers prior year actions and funding, FY2015 budget requests, hearings, and funding issues for legislative branch agencies. Funding levels for FY2014 and FY2015 budget requests are listed in tables, along with House, Senate, and conference bills and reports since FY1998. The FY2015 U.S. Budget includes a request for $4.471 billion in new budget authority for legislative branch activities. Table 2 lists the dates of hearings of the legislative branch subcommittees in 2014. The FY2015 U.S. Budget request for $4.471 billion for legislative branch activities was submitted on March 4, 2014. Hearings of legislative branch subcommittees in 2014 were listed in Table 2. On April 4, 2014, the House subcommittee marked up the FY2015 bill with $3.3 billion allocated. On April 9, 2014, the full House Appropriations Committee held a markup of the FY2015 bill. Representative Moran proposed a housing stipend of $25 per day for Members living 50 or more miles away from Washington, DC, which failed. On May 1, 2014, the House of Representatives considered H.R. 4487 with eight amendments, including one by Representative Nugent to prohibit MRA funding for vehicle leasing. On May 1, 2014, the House of Representatives considered H.R. 4487 with eight amendments, including one by Representative Nugent to prohibit MRA funding for vehicle leasing. Representative Speier also proposed allocating $500,000 for sexual harassment training in House offices, offset from the general administration fund of the Architect of the Capitol. An amendment to appropriate $500,000 for sexual harassment training in House offices was agreed to by voice vote. Another amendment to reduce funding for the Botanic Garden to FY2014 levels and transfer funds to the spending reduction account was agreed to by a vote of 219-198. An amendment to reduce funding for the Capitol Visitor Center by $243,000 and return it to FY2014 levels failed by a vote of 207-212. Another amendment to defund the Open World Leadership Center Trust Fund failed by voice vote. An amendment to prohibit funds from being used to deliver printed copies of the Statement of was agreed to. An amendment to reduce funding for the Capitol Visitor Center by $243,000 failed by a vote of 207-212. Another amendment to defund the Open World Leadership Center Trust Fund also failed. Additionally, amendments to prohibit the delivery of printed copies of the Statement of Disbursements and the House daily calendar to Members were agreed to by voice vote. The House passed H.R. 4487, with amendments including prohibiting funding for printed copies of the House daily calendar and reinstating the Office of Technology Assessment with $2.5 million. Another amendment to reduce funding for the Capitol Visitor Center failed. The House passed H.R. 4487 with amendments, including reinstating the Office of Technology Assessment with $2.5 million. The Senate Appropriations Committee considered the bill but no further action was taken before the start of FY2015. The House passed H.R. 4487 with amendments, including reinstating the Office of Technology Assessment with $2.5 million. The bill was reported favorably with an amendment in the nature of a substitute. No further action was taken on H.R. 4487 before the start of FY2015. Funding for the legislative branch was provided through continuing appropriations resolutions until the enactment of the Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act, 2015. The FY2015 act allocated $4.3 billion for legislative branch operations, a 1.0% increase from FY2014. The FY2015 Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act (P.L. 113-235) provided $4.3 billion for legislative branch operations, a 1.0% increase from FY2014. A funding gap led to a partial government shutdown for 16 days until a CR (P.L. 113-46) was enacted on October 17, 2013, providing funding through January 15, 2014. Prior to the fiscal year starting on October 1, 2013, a continuing appropriations resolution (CR) with FY2014 funding was enacted. This led to a 16-day partial government shutdown due to a funding gap. The shutdown ended with the enactment of a CR (P.L. 113-46) on October 17, 2013, providing funding until January 15, 2014. Additional funding for the legislative branch in FY2014 was provided by a consolidated appropriations bill on January 17 (P.L. 113-76), totaling $4.259 billion. Following the temporary continuing resolution on January 15, 2014 (P.L. 113-73), a consolidated appropriations bill on January 17 (P.L. 113-76) provided $4.259 billion for the legislative branch for FY2014, with FY2013 funding of approximately $4.061 billion from P.L. 113-6. The act funded legislative branch accounts at the FY2012 enacted level, with exceptions and less rescissions required by Section 3004 of P.L. 113-6. Section 3004 aimed to eliminate any excess budget authority beyond FY2013 discretionary spending limits. The act signed into law on March 26, 2013 funded legislative branch accounts at the FY2012 enacted level, with exceptions and less rescissions required by Section 3004 of P.L. 113-6 to eliminate excess budget authority beyond FY2013 discretionary spending limits. Subsequent to the enactment, OMB calculated additional rescissions of 0.032% of security budget authority and 0.2% of nonsecurity budget authority. The FY2013 discretionary spending limits were set by the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act, amended by the Budget Control Act of 2011 and the American Taxpayer Relief Act of 2012. OMB calculated additional rescissions of 0.032% of security budget authority and 0.2% of nonsecurity budget authority post-enactment of P.L. 113-6. Sequestration reductions implemented on March 1 remained unchanged, reducing most legislative branch accounts by 5.0%. Division G of the FY2012 Consolidated Appropriations Act (P.L. 112-74) provided details on canceled budget authority in each non-exempt account. The FY2013 discretionary spending limits were set by the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act, amended by the Budget Control Act of 2011 and the American Taxpayer Relief Act of 2012. OMB calculated additional rescissions of budget authority post-enactment of P.L. 113-6. Sequestration reductions implemented on March 1 reduced most legislative branch accounts by 5.0%. Division G of the FY2012 Consolidated Appropriations Act (P.L. 112-74) provided details on canceled budget authority in each non-exempt account, totaling $4.307 billion for the legislative branch, a decrease from previous years. The Appropriations Act (P.L. 112-74) allocated $4.307 billion for the legislative branch, a decrease of $236.9 million (-5.2%) from FY2011. This was lower than the $4.543 billion provided in FY2011 and the $4.668 billion in FY2010. Additional funding was given in FY2009, including $25.0 million for the Government Accountability Office (GAO) in the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009. In FY2009, the legislative branch budget received $4.402 billion from the Appropriations Act, with an additional $25.0 million allocated for the Government Accountability Office (GAO) in the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009. Funding was also provided for a Capitol Police radio system and the Congressional Budget Office (CBO) in P.L. 111-32. The budget in constant dollars remains below the FY2004 level. The Supplemental Appropriations Act included funding for a new Capitol Police radio system and the Congressional Budget Office. The legislative branch budget remains below the FY2004 level in constant dollars. The Senate requested $907.2 million for FY2015, with the final act providing $864.3 million. The Senate requested $907.2 million for FY2015, with the final act providing $864.3 million, an increase of 0.6%. The Senate Appropriations Committee recommended $865.9 million, an increase of 0.8% from FY2014. Additional information on the Senate account is presented in Table 5. Appropriations for Senate committees are contained in two accounts: The inquiries and investigations account contains funds for all Senate committees except Appropriations, with a recommended amount of $133.3 million for FY2015. The Senate requested $134.0 million for inquiries and investigations in FY2015, with the final act providing $133.3 million, an increase of 1.0% from FY2014. The Committee on Appropriations account contains funds for the Senate Appropriations Committee, with a requested amount of $14.94 million, the same as FY2014. The FY2015 act provided $15.1 million. The FY2015 act provided $133.3 million for the Senate Appropriations Committee, an increase of 1.0% from FY2014. The Senators' Official Personnel and Office Expense Account (SOPOEA) provides funds for each Senator's office expenses, including administrative, clerical, legislative assistance, and official office expenses. The Senators' Official Personnel and Office Expense Account (SOPOEA) provides funds for each Senator's office expenses, including administrative, clerical, legislative assistance, and official office expenses. The Senate requested $429.7 million for FY2015, but the Senate Appropriations Committee recommended and the FY2015 act provided $390.0 million, the same level as FY2014. The House requested $1.20 billion for FY2015, but the House-passed FY2015 level of $1.18 billion remained the same as FY2014. The Senate requested $429.7 million for FY2015, but the Senate Appropriations Committee recommended and the FY2015 act provided $390.0 million, the same level as FY2014. The House requested $1.20 billion for FY2015, but the House-passed FY2015 level of $1.18 billion remained the same as FY2014. Funding for House committees is contained in the appropriation heading "committee employees," which comprises two subheadings. The House of Representatives requested $126.3 million for FY2015, but the House-passed bill and FY2015 act provided $123.9 million, the same level as FY2014. Funding for House committees is under the "committee employees" heading, with two subheadings for expenses. The House of Representatives requested $126.3 million for FY2015, but the House-passed bill and FY2015 act provided $123.9 million, the same level as FY2014. The second subheading includes funds for the Committee on Appropriations, with a requested $23.7 million. The Members' Representational Allowance (MRA) for FY2015 was $565.4 million. The House requested $23.7 million for the Committee on Appropriations, while the Members' Representational Allowance (MRA) was $565.4 million for FY2015. The U.S. Capitol Police (USCP) requested $355.7 million for security purposes. The U.S. Capitol Police (USCP) requested $355.7 million for security in FY2015, an increase of 5.1% from the previous year. The House-passed bill would have provided $348.0 million, while the Senate-reported version would have provided $344.0 million. The final amount allocated was $554.3 million, the same as FY2014. The USCP requested $355.7 million for FY2015, with the House-passed bill providing $348.0 million and the Senate-reported version offering $344.0 million. The final allocation was $554.3 million, the same as FY2014. Appropriations for the police are divided into salaries and general expenses accounts. The police appropriations for FY2015 are presented in Table 7, divided into salaries and general expenses accounts. The salaries account covers employee salaries, benefits, and government contributions, while the general expenses account includes funds for various equipment, training programs, and services. The Capitol Police appropriations for FY2015 include funds for salaries, benefits, equipment, training programs, and services such as liability insurance. Salaries requested were $291.4 million, an increase of 4.4% from the previous year. The general expenses account covers expenses for vehicles, communication equipment, security equipment, dignitary protection, intelligence analysis, hazardous material response, uniforms, weapons, and other administrative and technical support. The Capitol Police requested $291.4 million for salaries, an increase of 4.4% from the previous year. They also requested $64.3 million for general expenses, an 8.1% increase. The House-passed bill would have provided $286.5 million for salaries and $61.5 million for general expenses. The Senate-reported bill recommended a $284.6 million budget for the Capitol Police, an increase of 2.0%. The House-passed bill in FY2015 provided the same level of funding. The Capitol Police also requested $25.6 million for buildings and grounds, a 32.3% increase from the previous year. The Committee recommended a $499 increase from the FY2014 enacted level for the Capitol Police. The House-passed bill in FY2015 provided $19.5 million, while the Senate-reported bill recommended $20.7 million. The USCP requested $25.6 million, a 32.3% increase from the previous year. Discussions in the House subcommittee included Capitol Police training requests, radio modernization program, recent incidents involving USCP, overtime use, and discrimination. The FY2015 act provided $19.2 million for the Capitol Police, which was a decrease of 1.0% from the previous year. Discussions in the House and Senate subcommittees focused on incidents involving the USCP, funding levels, and issues such as discrimination complaints and door closures in the Capitol. The Senate subcommittee discussed incidents involving the USCP, funding levels, and discrimination complaints related to door closures in the Capitol. The Office of Compliance requested $4.02 million for FY2015 to enforce workplace safety laws in Congress and legislative branch entities. The Office of Compliance, an independent agency in the legislative branch, administers the Congressional Accountability Act of 1995, applying employment and workplace safety laws to Congress. The requested budget for FY2015 was $4.02 million, with the House Appropriations Committee recommending $3.96 million. The House-passed bill included $4.5 million, with additional funds for sexual harassment training. The FY2015 budget for the Office of Compliance was $4.02 million, an increase of $152,000 from the previous year. The House Appropriations Committee recommended $3.96 million, while the House-passed bill included $4.5 million with funds for sexual harassment training. The Senate-reported bill proposed $3.96 million. The FY2015 act adopted the Senate-reported level and included language authorizing the Office of Compliance. The Senate-reported bill for the FY2015 budget allocated $3.96 million for the Office of Compliance, with an increase of $91,000 from the previous year. The bill also included language allowing electronic notifications to covered employees. The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) provides objective economic and budgetary analysis to Congress. The FY2015 act authorized the Office of Compliance to send electronic notifications to covered employees. The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) requested $46.1 million for FY2015. The House-passed bill allocated $45.7 million, while the Senate-reported bill allocated $46.1 million. The House level was provided in the FY2015 act. At a House hearing on March 4, 2014, the subcommittee discussed CBO's workload. The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) requested $46.1 million for FY2015, with the House-passed bill providing $45.7 million and the Senate-reported bill providing $46.1 million. Discussions at hearings included CBO projections, findings, and methodologies. CBO also requested two administrative provisions, including funds for employee compensation. The subcommittee discussed CBO projections and recent findings. At a Senate subcommittee hearing on March 11, 2014, they discussed the number of requests received by CBO and its methodologies. CBO requested two administrative provisions for FY2015 funds, which were not included in H.R. 4487 or the FY2015 act. The Architect of the Capitol is responsible for maintenance and operation. The Architect of the Capitol is responsible for the maintenance, operation, development, and preservation of the U.S. Capitol Complex, including various buildings and grounds. A provision in H.R. 4487 would address compensation for employees in specialty occupations with non-immigrant visas. The Architect of the Capitol oversees the maintenance, operation, development, and preservation of the U.S. Capitol Complex, including various buildings and grounds. Operations are funded through 10 accounts for general administration, Capitol building, grounds, Senate and House office buildings, power plant, Library buildings, Capitol Police buildings. The Architect of the Capitol requested $676.6 million for FY2015, a 12.4% increase from FY2014, including funds for the Capitol Dome restoration project. The House-reported bill proposed $488.6 million, excluding dome restoration funding. The Architect of the Capitol requested $676.6 million for FY2015, a 12.4% increase from FY2014, including funds for the Capitol Dome restoration project. The FY2015 act also included language prohibiting the use of funds for bonuses for contractors behind schedule or over budget. Discussions at the House subcommittee hearing on March 4, 2014, included funding for the Capitol Dome rehabilitation project, project prioritization, and plans for the renovation of the Cannon House Office Building. The House and Senate discussed funding for Capitol Dome rehabilitation, project prioritization, and renovation plans. The Library of Congress serves as Congress's library and the national library of the United States, providing acquisition and maintenance services. The Senate subcommittee discussed the restoration of the Capitol Dome and project prioritization at a hearing in the Cannon House Office Building on April 8, 2014. The Library of Congress serves as Congress's library and the national library of the United States, providing various services including acquisition, maintenance, preservation of a collection of over 158 million items, and administration of U.S. copyright laws. The Library of Congress manages a collection of over 158 million items in various media formats, provides services to the public and scholarly communities, administers U.S. copyright laws, and offers reading materials to the blind and physically handicapped. It also provides legal research services to Congress through the Law Library and conducts nonpartisan policy research and legislative assistance through the Congressional Research Service. The Library of Congress provides services to the public, scholarly communities, and Congress. It manages a collection of over 158 million items and offers reading materials to the blind and physically handicapped. The Library requested $593.1 million for FY2015, an increase of 2.4% from the previous year. The House-passed bill would have provided $594.95 million. The Library of Congress requested $593.1 million for FY2015, an increase of 2.4% from the previous year. The House-passed bill would have provided $594.95 million, while the Senate-reported bill would have provided $587.4 million. The FY2015 act ultimately provided $590.9 million, an increase of $11.9 million (+2.1%). The FY2015 budget for the Library of Congress includes $590.9 million, an increase of $11.9 million (+2.1%) from the previous year. Salaries and expenses were allocated $413.0 million, while the Copyright Office received $19.5 million. The Open World Leadership Center supports democratic changes in other countries by inviting their leaders to observe democracy and free enterprise in the United States. The Open World Leadership Center, established in 1999 by Congress, administers a program to support democratic changes in other countries by inviting their leaders to observe democracy and free enterprise in the United States. Initially focused on the relationship between Russia and the United States, the program expanded in 2003 to include specified activities. The Open World Leadership Center, established in 1999 by Congress, supports democratic changes in other countries by inviting their leaders to observe democracy and free enterprise in the United States. Initially focused on Russia and the United States, the program expanded in 2003 to include additional countries. The center is housed in the Library of Congress and receives services through an inter-agency agreement. Open World requested $8.0 million for FY2015. In 2004, Congress extended the Open World Leadership Center program's eligibility to other countries designated by the center's board of trustees. Open World requested $8.0 million for FY2015, an increase of 33.3% from the previous year. The House-passed bill proposed a reduction to $3.42 million (-43.0%) in consultation with House leadership. The House report stated that future budget requests must be accompanied by a detailed budget justification as per previous directives. The Center was created by Congress in 1988 with an appropriation. The Committee did not receive the requested funding of $430,000 for the Stennis Center as justification was not provided. The Center was created by Congress in 1988 with an initial appropriation of $7.5 million, which has since grown to $15 million invested with the Treasury. The John C. Stennis Center for Public Service Training and Development, established by Congress in 1988 with an initial appropriation of $7.5 million, now has $15 million invested with the Treasury. Despite the fund doubling in size, reduced funding within the Legislative Branch has led to zero funding being provided for the Center. The Committee has provided zero funding for the John C. Stennis Center for Public Service Training and Development due to reduced funding within the Legislative Branch. Any future budget requests from the Center must be accompanied by a detailed budget justification. The Center was funded at $430,000 in previous fiscal years. The Committee directs that future budget requests from the John C. Stennis Center must include a detailed budget justification. The Center received $430,000 in funding in previous fiscal years. The House-passed and Senate-reported versions of H.R. 4487 and P.L. 113-235 included provisions on prohibiting funds for private vehicle maintenance, limiting funds to FY2015, making compensation changes permanent, disclosing consulting services contracts, authorizing LBFMC costs, AOC landscape maintenance, limiting transfers, and allowing staff tours of the Capitol. The House-passed and Senate-reported versions of H.R. 4487 included provisions on disclosing consulting services contracts, authorizing LBFMC costs, AOC landscape maintenance, limiting transfers, and prohibiting restrictions on staff tours of the Capitol. Additionally, a provision freezing pay for Members of Congress in 2015 was enacted in Division N of the FY2015 act. The Senate-reported bill included restrictions on bonus awards to contractors for projects behind schedule or over budget, as well as provisions prohibiting funds for painting portraits of federal government officials.
